column1: Obesity in children and teens is a serious health problem.
A child who is overweight or obese is more likely to be overweight or obese as an adult.
A child who is overweight or obese is also more likely to have problems such as: - Low self-esteem - Poor grades in school - Depression

This weight loss can have health benefits such as: - Better control of diabetes - Lower cholesterol and blood pressure - Fewer sleep problems In the United States, weight loss operations have been used with success in teenagers.

After any weight-loss surgery, your child will: - Have a smaller stomach - Feel full or satisfied with less food - Not be able to eat as much as before The most common operation now offered to teens is the vertical sleeve gastrectomy.
The body mass index (BMI) measures below are used by many doctors to decide who can be helped the most by weight-loss surgery.

The general guidelines are: A BMI of 35 or higher and a serious health condition related to obesity, such as: - Diabetes (high blood sugar) - Pseudotumor cerebri (increased pressure inside the skull) - Moderate or severe sleep apnea (symptoms include daytime sleepiness and loud snoring, gasping, and holding breath while asleep) - Severe inflammation of the liver that is caused by excess fat A BMI of 40 or higher and a less serious health condition related to obesity, such as: - High blood pressure - High cholesterol - Mild sleep apnea - Depression Other factors should also be considered before a child or teenager has weight-loss surgery.
Is Weight-loss Surgery Safe for Teens?
However, too little research has been done to show if there are any long-term effects on growth for teens that undergo weight loss surgery.
